description:
'''Death Cab for Cutie''' (commonly abbreviated to '''DCFC''' or '''Death Cab''') is an American [[rock music|rock]] band formed in [[Bellingham, Washington]], in 1997. Death Cab for Cutie's music has been classified as [[indie rock]], [[indie pop]], and [[alternative rock]]. The band is currently{{when|date=March 2025}} composed of [[Ben Gibbard]] (vocals, guitar, piano), Nick Harmer (bass), [[Dave Depper]] (guitar, keyboards, backing vocals), [[Zac Rae]] (keyboards, guitar), and [[Jason McGerr]] (drums).

The band was originally a solo project by Gibbard, who expanded the project into a complete group upon getting a record deal. They released their debut album, ''[[Something About Airplanes]]'', in 1998. The band's fourth album, 2003's ''[[Transatlanticism]]'', broke into the mainstream both critically and commercially; its songs were featured in various TV series and films. The band's major label debut for [[Atlantic Records]], 2005's ''[[Plans (album)|Plans]]'', went [[platinum certification|platinum]]. Founding guitarist [[Chris Walla]] left the band in 2014 after 17 years. The band's tenth and latest studio album, ''[[Asphalt Meadows]]'', was released on September 16, 2022. Alongside their ten full-length studio albums, the band has released four [[Extended Play|EPs]], two live EPs, one [[live album]], and one demo album.

Gibbard took the band name from the song "[[Death Cab for Cutie (song)|Death Cab for Cutie]]", which was written by [[Neil Innes]] and [[Vivian Stanshall]] and recorded by their group the [[Bonzo Dog Doo-Dah Band]]. The song is a track on the Bonzo's 1967 debut album, ''[[Gorilla (Bonzo Dog Doo-Dah Band album)|Gorilla]]'', and was performed by them in the Beatles film ''[[Magical Mystery Tour (film)|Magical Mystery Tour]]''. The title was originally that of a story in an old [[pulp magazine|pulp fiction crime magazine]] that Innes came across in a street market. In a 2011 interview, Gibbard stated, "The name was never supposed to be something that someone was going to reference 15 years on. So yeah, I would absolutely go back and give it a more obvious name."

Death Cab for Cutie have been called "one of the definitive indie bands of the 2000s and 2010s."
